revisions.rev:
{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1970 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = 3 | APRank = 1 | Record = 11-0-1 | ConfRecord = 7-0-0 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Bob Devaney]] | HCYear = 9th | OffCoach = [[Tom Osborne]] | OCYear = 2nd | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = [[I formation]] | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = Big 8 Champions
Orange Bowl Champions
AP National Champions | BowlTourney = [[1971 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] vs. #5 {{cfb link|year=1970|school=Louisiana State University|team=LSU Tigers|title=LSU}} | BowlTourneyResult = W 17-12 | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1970 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1970 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1970 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Bob Devaney]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. The Huskers went 11-0-1 to win the first of two consecutive [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national championships]]. ==Overview== The Huskers started the season at #9 and tied #3 [[1970 USC Trojans football team|USC]] in [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum|Los Angeles]] in the second game of the season. After winning their next nine games, including all seven in the [[Big Eight Conference|Big 8]], Nebraska was ranked third in the nation entering the [[1971 Orange Bowl]] against #5 [[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] of the [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]]. Top-ranked [[1970 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]] and #2 [[1970 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] both lost their [[bowl games]] earlier in the [[New Year's Day|day]] and a 17-12 Nebraska victory that night in [[Miami, Florida|Miami]] gave the Huskers their first [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national title]]. Through the [[1973 college football season|1973 season]], the final [[United Press International|UPI]] [[Coaches' Poll|coaches poll]] was released in early December, '''before''' the [[bowl games]]. In 1970 it picked Texas as national champion on December 8, before the Longhorns' 24-11 loss to [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] in the [[Cotton Bowl Classic|1971 Cotton Bowl]] in [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] on [[New Year's Day]]. Notre Dame (10-1) finished second to Nebraska (11-0-1) in the final [[AP Poll#College football|AP]] writers poll, released after the bowls in early January. ==Schedule== {{CFB Schedule Start|rankyear=1970|tv=|attend=yes}} {{CFB Schedule Entry | w/l = w | date = September 12 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = | rank = 9 | away = | neutral = | opprank = | opponent = [[1970 Wake Forest Demon Deacons football team|Wake Forest]] | site_stadium = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]], [[Nebraska]] | gamename = | tv = | score = 36-12 | overtime = | attend = 66,103 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | w/l = t | date = September 19 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = | rank = 9 | away = yes | neutral = | opprank = 3 | opponent = [[1970 USC Trojans football team|USC]] | site_stadium = [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum|L.A. ||align="center"|1970-71||align="center"|[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |} ==Game notes== ===Wake Forest=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Wake Forest at #9 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1970 Wake Forest Demon Deacons football team|Wake Forest]] | Host = '''#9 Nebraska''' | V1 = 3| V2 = 2| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 14| H2 = 14| H3 = 8| H4 = 0 | Date = 1970-09-12 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,103 }} {{AFB game box end}} Wake Forest hit first with a field goal thanks to a Nebraska fumble, but by the half it was the Cornhuskers 28-5. The Demon Deacons would go on to win the ACC title. {{-}} ===USC=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Nebraska at #3 USC''' [box score] | Visitor = #9 Nebraska | Host = #3 [[1970 USC Trojans football team|USC]] | V1 = 0| V2 = 14| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 7| H4 = 7 | Date = 1970-09-19 | Location = [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]], [[Los Angeles, California]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 73,768 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska entered the game as a two-touchdown underdog, but never trailed the Trojans during the course of the game. Each team traded touchdowns, and each team missed opportunities for the win, right up to USC's incomplete 50 yard pass on the last play of the game. {{-}} ===Army=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Army at #8 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1970|school=United States Military Academy|team=Army Black Knights|title=Army}} | Host = '''#8 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1970-09-26 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 66,928 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska owned the day, shutting out Army 28-0 in an otherwise unremarkable game. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#6 Nebraska at Minnesota''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#6 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1970 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | V1 = 21| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 7| H2 = 3| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1970-10-03 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium (University of Minnesota)|Memorial Stadium]], [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 52,287 }} {{AFB game box end}} Bob Devaney's record against the Big 10 was extended to 9-0 as the Cornhuskers had little trouble with Minnesota after running ahead 28-10 before the half. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#16 Missouri at #6 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #16 {{cfb link|year=1970|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} | Host = '''#6 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 14 | Date = 1970-10-10 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,538 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska scored only 7 points in the first half, and Missouri matched it before the half. The subsequent defensive battle continued through into the 4th quarter before the Cornhuskers broke away with an additional 14 points, one from a 48 yard punt return touchdown. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#5 Nebraska at Kansas''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#5 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1970|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | V1 = 10| V2 = 14| V3 = 7| V4 = 10 | H1 = 6| H2 = 14| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1970-10-17 | Location = [[University of Kansas Memorial Stadium|McCook Field]], [[Lawrence, Kansas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 50,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska was surprised to find themselves behind 10-20 with 10 minutes left in the 1st half, but battled back to take the lead with two more touchdowns before the break, and never let Kansas score again as they cruised to a 41-20 final. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Oklahoma State at #4 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1970|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | Host = '''#4 Nebraska''' | V1 = 7| V2 = 0| V3 = 6| V4 = 18 | H1 = 14| H2 = 27| H3 = 10| H4 = 14 | Date = 1970-10-24 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,822 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska piled up 65 points, its highest total since 1922, and held Oklahoma State to just 64 ground yards as the Cornhuskers made short work of the Cowboys. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#4 Nebraska at Colorado''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#4 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1970|school=University of Colorado at Boulder|team=Colorado Buffaloes|title=Colorado}} | V1 = 12| V2 = 0| V3 = 3| V4 = 14 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 6 | Date = 1970-10-31 | Location = [[Folsom Field]], [[Boulder, Colorado]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 50,881 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska pulled out in front right away with a 12-0 1st quarter lead, but stubborn Colorado fought back and trailed the Cornhuskers by only 13-15 in the 4th quarter - after missing a 2 point conversion that would have tied the game - before Nebraska decided to stop the uprising with two touchdowns in the last 10 minutes to pull away. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#4 Nebraska at Iowa State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#4 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1970|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | V1 = 12| V2 = 14| V3 = 21| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 11| H3 = 6| H4 = 12 | Date = 1970-11-07 | Location = Clyde Williams Field, [[Ames, Iowa]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 36,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} The game was not as close as the score indicates, as Iowa State put up two late touchdowns against Nebraska reserves in the 4th quarter after the Cornhuskers had run up a 54-17 lead with 5 minutes remaining to play. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#20 Kansas State at #4 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #20 [[1970 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]] | Host = '''#4 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 6 | H1 = 14| H2 = 7| H3 = 16| H4 = 14 | Date = 1970-11-14 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,894 }} {{AFB game box end}} Kansas State came to Lincoln with hopes of a Big 8 title opportunity, but they were not prepared for the domination that Nebraska would show them in a convincing defeat. The Wildcats managed only two touchdowns, one of which came with 5 minutes remaining in the 4th against the Nebraska reserves. At one point in the game, the Cornhuskers exploded for 27 points in less than 4 minutes, pushing their lead out to 51-7. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Oklahoma at #3 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1970 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] | Host = '''#3 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 14| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 0| H2 = 14| H3 = 7| H4 = 7 | Date = 1970-11-21 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,392 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska locked up their first unbeaten regular season since 1965 by coming from behind twice to get the win over stubborn Oklahoma. It wasn't until 7:42 remainined in the 4th quarter that Nebraska pulled ahead by a touchdown to settle the final score. {{-}} ===Louisiana State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#3 Nebraska vs #5 Louisiana State''' [box score] | Visitor = #5 {{cfb link|year=1970|school=Louisiana State University|team=LSU Tigers|title=LSU}} | Host = '''#3 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 3| V3 = 9| V4 = 0 | H1 = 10| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1971-01-01 | Location = [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]], [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], [[Florida]] | StartTime = 8:35 pm | TimeZone = EST | Attendance = 80,699 }} {{AFB game box end}} Third-ranked Nebraska jumped to a 10-0 lead in the first quarter and lead 10-3 at halftime, but #5 LSU fought back to make a game of it, pulling ahead on a field goal at the end of the 3rd quarter to get to 12-10. With over eight minutes remaining, [[Jerry Tagge]] jumped over the pile from the 1-yard line for the game's final points, and the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] held on the rest of the way to preserve the win. Top-ranked [[1970 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]] and #2 [[1970 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] both lost their [[bowl game]]s earlier in the [[New Year's Day|day]], which allowed the Huskers to claim their first [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national championship]]. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{See also|1970 college football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- ! Jerry Tagge, Wally Winter |} ==1970 Team Players in the NFL== The 1970 Nebraska Cornhuskers seniors selected in the [[1971 NFL Draft]]: [http://www.pro-football-reference.com/draft/1971.htm Pro Football Reference.com] -
